The first stage of the pipeline expands (at 763) the JPEG-compressed contone CMYK layer, expands (at 764) the Group 4 Fax-compressed bi-level black layer, and renders (at 766) the bi-level netpage tag layer according to the tag format defined in section 1.2, all in parallel. The second stage dithers (at 765) the contone CMYK layer and composites (at 765) the bi-level black layer over the resulting bi-level CMYK layer. The resultant bi-level CMYK+IR dot data is buffered and formatted (at 767) for printing on the Memjet(TM) printhead 350 via a set of line buffers. Most of these line buffers are stored in the off-chip DRAM. The final stage prints the six channels of bi-level dot data (including fixative) to the Memjet(TM) printhead 350 via the printhead interface 768.

When several print engine controllers 760 are used in unison, such as in a duplexed configuration, they are synchronized via a shared line sync signal 770. Only one print engine 760, selected via the external master/slave pin 771, generates the line sync signal 770 onto the shared line.

The print engine controller 760 contains a low-speed processor 772 for synchronizing the page expansion and rendering pipeline, configuring the printhead 350 via a low-speed serial bus 773, and controlling the stepper motors 675, 676.

In the 8[1/2]'' versions of the netpage printer, the two print engines each prints 30 Letter pages per minute along the long dimension of the page (11''), giving a line rate of 8.8 kHz at 1600 dpi. In the 12'' versions of the netpage printer, the two print engines each prints 45 Letter pages per minute along the short dimension of the page (8[1/2]''), giving a line rate of 10.2 kHz. These line rates are well within the operating frequency of the Memjet(TM) printhead, which in the current design exceeds 30 kHz.
8 Netpage Greeting Cards

The netpage system provides an application whereby a user can create a customised greeting card by selecting an image and a greeting message, and adding a handwritten message. The card can be sent to the recipient either directly to their default netpage printer, or to their postal address.

A user can select a greeting card from an on-line catalogue, add a handwritten message, and dispatch it via the netpage network. Cards can be addressed to other netpage users, and to normal postal addresses. In the latter case the card is printed at the service centre closest to the recipient, automatically placed in an envelope, and mailed through the local mail system.
Netpage users can choose to receive cards from anyone, or only from authorised friends.
8.1 Application Diagram Notation

Each application user interface flow is illustrated as a collection of documents linked by command arrows. A command arrow indicates that the target document is printed as a result of the user pressing the corresponding command button on the source page. Some command arrows are labelled with multiple commands separated by slashes ('/'s), indicating that any one of the specified commands causes the target document to be printed. Although multiple commands may label the same command arrow, they typically have different side-effects.

In application terms, it is important to distinguish between netpage documents and netpage forms. Documents contain printed information, as well as command buttons which can be pressed by the user to request further information or some other action. Forms, in addition to behaving like normal documents, also contain input fields which can be filled in by the user. They provide the system with a data input mechanism. It is also useful to distinguish between documents which contain generic information and documents which contain information specific to a particular interaction between the user and an application. Generic documents may be pre-printed publications such as magazines sold at news stands or advertising posters encountered in public places. Forms may also be pre-printed, including, for example, subscription forms encountered in pre-printed publications. They may, of course, also be generated on-the-fly by a netpage printer in response to user requests. User-specific documents and forms are normally generated on the fly by a netpage printer in response to user requests. FIG. 48 shows a generic document 990, a generic form 991, a user-specific document 992, and a user-specific form 993.

Netpages which participate in a user interface flow are further described by abstract page layouts. A page layout may contain various kinds of elements, each of which has a unique style to differentiate it from the others. As shown in FIG. 49, these include fixed information 994, variable information 995, input fields 996, command buttons 997, and draggable commands 998.
When a user interface flow is broken up into multiple diagrams, any document which is duplicated is shown with dashed outlines in all but the main diagram which defines it.
8.2 Greeting Cards Object Model
The greeting cards object model revolves around a greeting card supplier, customers and customised greeting cards. The Greeting Cards class diagram 500 is shown in FIG. 50.

Each supplier 501 has a unique identifier and a name 501a. Each customer 502 is related to a particular supplier, and has an identifier 503 which is unique within the scope of the particular supplier.
Each customer 502 represents a particular netpage user 800 to the supplier. A netpage user, on the other hand, can be the customer of any number of suppliers.
The name and description of a customer 502 derive by default from the details of the corresponding netpage user 800.
Each supplier 501 has a number of categories 505 of greeting cards. Each category has a number of card images 525 and a number of card messages 507.

A customer 502 can create a customised card 508. Each customised card has a unique identifier 509, the date and time the card was created, the custom message handwritten by the user (stored as digital ink), and a fee. Each customised card has a recipient 510. If the recipient is another netpage user, the card is delivered directly to their default netpage printer. If the recipient is not a netpage user, the customer specifies the name and postal address for delivery of the card. The Card Recipient class diagram 511 is shown in FIG. 52.

Each customer 502 has an account 512 with the supplier 501, with a running balance 513. Account payments 547 are associated directly with the customer account. The payments class diagram 514 is shown in FIG. 51. Each customer has a history of payment methods 515 with the supplier. The set of payment methods 516 to 519 supported by a particular supplier will be specific to that supplier, and may be different for different customers depending on their credit ratings etc.
When the netpage account payment method 516 is used, the user's netpage account 820 is debited, and the transaction appears on the user's netpage account statement.
When the customer account payment method 517 is used, the user is invoiced for payment.
When the SET payment method 519 is used, the corresponding SET payment card 821 linked to the user is used to make payment according to the normal SET protocol.

When the payment card payment method 518 is used, the specified payment card is used to make payment according to the normal protocol between the provider and their acquiring bank or institution which handles the particular payment card type.
Each payment has a unique payment number, the date and time of the payment, the amount paid, and a receipt number.

Netpage users may receive cards from anyone, or only from authorized friends, depending on their netpage e-mail settings. If the user's e-mail privacy setting is such that e-mails may only be received from members of their contact list, then greeting cards may also only be received from members of the same contact list.
8.3 Greeting Cards User Interface
The user may obtain the Netpage Greeting Cards main page 522 from a variety of links including:
the netpage directory
the netpage user's own bookmark
an advertisement

The Netpage Greeting Card user interface flow is shown in FIG. 53, where it can be seen that the user is also able to access card images 525, account 512 details and register with the supplier at 523.
8.3.1 Registering

The user can register with the greeting card supplier by clicking on the <Register> button 524 on the Greeting Card main page 522, shown in FIG. 56. A User Registration form (not shown) is printed. When a user registers, an account is created for the user and the user is then permitted to create and send customized greeting cards.
8.3.2 Creating a Customised Greeting Card

The Greeting Card main page 522, shown in FIG. 56, shows the greeting card categories 505. The user clicks on the desired category. If the user is registered with the greeting card supplier the Card Image List 525 is printed, as shown in FIG. 57. If the user is not already registered with the supplier a User Registration form is printed.

The Card Image list shows thumbnails 526 of the available images for the front page of the customized greeting card. Only two double-sided pages are printed at a time. Each time the user clicks <More> 527 another two double-sided pages of thumbnail images are printed. The user selects an image by clicking on it. The Greeting Card Messages page 528 is printed as shown in FIG. 58.

The Greeting Card Messages page 528 shows the stock messages available for inclusion on the inside page of the customized greeting card. Only two double-sided pages are printed at a time. Each time the user clicks <More> 529 another two double-sided pages of card messages are printed. The user selects a message by clicking on it. The Personal Message page 530 is printed as shown in FIG. 59.

The Personal Message page allows the user to enter a handwritten message 531 on the inside page of the card, along with the stock card message 532. The user can click <Preview Card> 533 to print a sample of the card 534 as it will appear to the recipient, as shown in FIGS. 63 and 64. The user clicks <Continue> 535 and the Recipient Address form 536 is printed, as shown in FIG. 11.
The Recipient Address form 536 shows the image 525 and messages 531, 532 for the customized greeting card.

If the recipient 510 is a netpage user, the user enters one or more of the recipient's first name, initials, nickname, and family name. If the recipient is not a netpage user then the user enters the recipient's name and postal address in the fields provided. The name and address are printed on an envelope as is (i.e. "handwritten"). The user clicks <Continue> 537.

If the recipient is a netpage user the system first looks for matches in the user's contact list. If a single match is found in the user's contact list then the Pay and Send form 541 is printed, with the recipient details shown.

If there are no matches with the user's contact list then the global user directory is searched, and the results printed on one or more User Directory Matches pages. The user selects the desired recipient by pressing the <Select> button next to the required user name.

If there is more than one match with the user's contact list then the Contact List page 538 is printed, as shown in FIG. 61. The user selects the desired recipient 510 by pressing the <Select> button 539 next to the required user name. If the desired recipient does not appear in the contact list the user presses the <User Directory> button 540 to automatically search the global user directory for matches. The matching entries are printed on one or more User Directory Matches (not shown) pages. The user selects the desired recipient by pressing the <Select> button next to the required user name.
Once a single netpage user has been selected as the recipient a Pay and Send form 541 is printed, as shown in FIG. 62.

The Pay and Send form 541 shows all details of the customized greeting card 508 and shows the fee 542 for delivery of the card. The user signs the form and clicks <Send Card> 543. The fee is added to the user's customer account balance 513, and the card is sent to the recipient.

If the recipient is a netpage user the card is printed directly to their default netpage printer. If the recipient is not a netpage user then the country and city are extracted from the recipient address. The envelope and card are printed at the country and city specific service center and mailed through the local mail system.

The Compose Greeting Card function is a multi-page transaction. To assist the user in keeping track of the pages relevant to a single greeting card, the transaction number and the current date and time are printed at the top of each page. The user can click a <Reset Form> button at the bottom of any page to void the current form and print a fresh form as part of the current transaction.
The user interface flow 544 for creating and sending a customized greeting card is shown in FIG. 54. The user interface flow 545 for addressing a card is shown in FIG. 55.
8.3.3 Making an Account Payment

The user can view their account details by clicking the <View Account> button 546 on the Greeting Card main page, shown in FIG. 56. An Account Details page (not shown) is printed giving details of the charges and payments, and the outstanding balance for the user's account. The user can select to make a payment to their account from this page using one of the available payment methods.
CONCLUSION

The present invention has been described with reference to a preferred embodiment and number of specific alternative embodiments. However, it will be appreciated by those skilled in the relevant fields that a number of other embodiments, differing from those specifically described, will also fall within the spirit and scope of the present invention. Accordingly, it will be understood that the invention is not intended to be limited to the specific embodiments described in the present specification, including documents incorporated by cross-reference as appropriate. The scope of the invention is only limited by the attached claims.

titleStmt.title: SYSTEM FOR ENABLING USER INTERACTION WITH COMPUTER SOFTWARE

div.p: A system for enabling user interaction with computer software is provided which has a printer. The printer receives print data, prints a form using the print data, receives indicating data from a sensing device and transfers the indicating data to a computer system. The form is printed by printing information related to at least one interactive element associated with the delivery of a greeting card and coded data indicative of the interactive element. At least some of the coded data is printed to be coincident with the information. The sensing device senses at least some of the coded data and generates the indicating data using the sensed coded data. The indicating data generated is at least partially indicative of the interactive element. The computer system interprets the transferred indicating data.
1. A system for enabling user interaction with computer software, the system including a printer for:
receiving print data;
printing a form, using the print data, by printing:
information related to at least one interactive element associated with the delivery of a greeting card; and,
coded data at least partially indicative of the at least one interactive element, at least some of the coded data being coincident with the information;

receiving indicating data from a sensing device, the sensing device when placed in an operative position relative to the information, sensing at least some of the coded data and generating indicating data using the sensed coded data, the indicating data being at least partially indicative of the at least one interactive element; and,
transferring the indicating data to a computer system to allow the indicating data to be interpreted.
2. The system of claim 1, wherein the coded data is at least partially indicative of an identity, and wherein the computer system is for:
determining, using the indicating data, the identity;
determining, using the identity, a page description; and,
identifying, using the page description, the at least one interactive element.
3. The system of claim 2, wherein the identity is at least one of:
an identity of the form;
an identity of a region of the form; and,
an identity of the at least one interactive element.

4. The system of claim 1, wherein the indicating data is at least partially indicative of a stroke, the stroke defining a sequence of sensing device positions determined from the sensed coded data, the sequence of sensing device positions being at least one of:
a sequence of relative positions; and,
a sequence of absolute positions.

5. The system of claim 4, wherein the coded data includes a number of data portions, each data portion having a unique data portion identity indicative of a location of the coded data portion on the form, and wherein the computer system is for:
determining, from the indicating data, the data portion identity of each sensed data portion;
determining, using each data portion identity and a map, the location of each sensed data portion;
determining from each location, the movement of the sensing device relative to the at least one interactive element.

6. The system of claim 4, wherein the coded data includes a number of data portions, each data portion coincident with the at least one interactive element having an identical data portion identity, wherein the indicating data is generated by:
sensing a number of images of the coded data;
comparing the images to determine common features in sequential images; and,
determine movement of the sensing device relative to the at least one interactive element by determining changes in position of the common features between the sequential images.

7. The system of claim 4, wherein the stoke is indicative of a hand-written text input, and wherein the computer system is for performing text recognition on the handwritten text input, thereby to generate computer text.
8. The system of claim 4, wherein the computer system is for:
determining, using the stroke, a handwritten signature; and,
determining, using a user identity, a predetermined signature;
verifying the user by comparing the handwritten signature to the predetermined signature.
9. The system of claim 8, wherein the indicating data includes an identifier obtained from the sensing device, and wherein the computer system is for:
determining, using the indicating data, the identifier; and,
determining, using the identifier, the user identity.
10. The system of claim 1, wherein the system includes the sensing device, the sensing device comprising:
(a) an image sensor adapted to capture images of at least some of the coded data when the sensing device is placed in an operative position relative to the interface surface; and
(b) a processor adapted to:
(i) identify at least some of the coded data from at least one of the captured images;
(ii) determine an orientation and position, within at least one of the captured images, of at least some of the coded data;
(iii) decode at least some of the coded data; and
(iv) generate the indicating data using at least some of the decoded coded data and the determined orientation and position.
11. The system of claim 10, wherein the printer includes:
a first communications module for communicating with the sensing device; and,
a second communications module for communicating with the computer system.

12. The system of claim 10, wherein the sensing device includes a data store for storing a sensing device identifier, and wherein the sensing device generates the indicating data using the identifier, the printer using the identifier to receive any response from the computer system.
13. A system according to claim 1, wherein the computer system is for transferring the print data to the printer.
14. The system of claim 13, wherein the computer system is for:
determining the information;
determining an identity, the identity being at least partially indicative of the at least one interactive element;
determining a layout defining an arrangement for at least one of:
coded data at least partially indicative of the identity; and, the information;
recording an association between the layout and the identity; and,
generating the print data, the print data being at least partially indicative of:
the identity;
the layout; and
the information.
15. The system of claim 1, wherein the computer system is for determining, using the interactive element, at least one of:
a message associated with the card;
a recipient address; and,
a selected one of a number of available cards.
16. The system of claim 15, wherein the form includes a list formed from a number of list items, including at least one of:
a number of card categories and images of the greeting cards of each category;
a number of recipient addresses;
a number of messages for inclusion in the card; and,
wherein the computer is for determining, using the indicating data, a selected list item.
17. The system of claim 1, wherein a recipient address of the greeting card corresponds to at least one of:
a printer address and the card is delivered by printing at that address;
an electronic mail address and an image of the card is delivered to that address; and,
a street address and the card is sent to a proximate mail service for printing and delivery to the street address.

Whenever the pen is within range of a printer with which it can communicate, the pen slowly flashes its "online" LED. When the pen fails to decode a stroke relative to the page, it momentarily activates its "error" LED. When the pen succeeds in decoding a stroke relative to the page, it momentarily activates its "ok" LED.
test aaa
CROSS REFERENCE TO RELATED APPLICATIONS
The present application is a continuation of U.S. application Ser. No. 09/575,116 filed May 5, 2000, the entire contents of which are herein incorporated by reference.
FIELD OF INVENTION

The present invention relates generally to methods, systems and apparatus for interacting with computers by means of printed matter and sensing devices. More particularly, the invention relates to delivery of a greeting card, utilizing such methods, systems and apparatus.

The invention has been developed primarily to allow a large number of distributed users to interact with networked information via printed matter and optical sensors, thereby to obtain interactive printed matter on demand via high-speed networked color printers. Although the invention will largely be described herein with reference to this use, it will be appreciated that the invention is not limited to use in this field.
CO-PENDING APPLICATIONS
The disclosures of these co-pending applications are incorporated herein by cross-reference.
BACKGROUND

Paper is widely used to display and record information. Printed information is easier to read than information displayed on a computer screen. Hand-drawing and handwriting afford greater richness of expression than input via a computer keyboard and mouse. Moreover, paper doesn't run on batteries, can be read in bright light, more robustly accepts coffee spills, and is portable and disposable.

Online publication has many advantages over traditional paper-based publication. From a consumer's point of view, information is available on demand, information can be navigated via hypertext links, searched and automatically personalized.

From the publisher's point of view, the costs of printing and physical distribution are eliminated, and the publication becomes more attractive to the advertisers who pay for it because it can be targeted to specific demographics and linked to product sites.

Online publication also has disadvantages. Computer screens are inferior to paper. At the same quality as a magazine page, an SVGA computer screen displays only about a fifth as much information. Both CRTs and LCDs have brightness and contrast problems, particularly when ambient light is strong, while ink on paper, being reflective rather than emissive, is both bright and sharp in ambient light.
SUMMARY OF INVENTION
In accordance with the invention, there is provided a method of selecting and delivering a greeting card, including:

providing a document with details of a selection of available greeting cards, the document having at least one user-interactive element with which a user interacts to select a card using a sensing device adapted to transmit interaction data to a computer system;
indicating selection of a card using the sensing device;
including a message using the sensing device; and
sending the card to a recipient address via the computer system.
In another aspect, there is provided a method of enabling selection and delivery of a greeting card, including:

obtaining a document with details of a selection of available greeting cards, the document having at least one user-interactive element with which a user interacts to select a card using a sensing device adapted to transmit interaction data to a computer system;
receiving, in the computer system, data indicating selection of a card including a message in the selected card, the message being user specified using the sensing device; and
sending the card to a recipient address via the computer system.

Preferably, the details are presented as a list of card categories and images of the greeting cards of each category are printed for viewing in a further document by selecting the respective category using the sensing device.

Preferably, the step of including a message comprises selecting a message from a list of messages and the list is preferably provided in a further document which is printed after the card is selected, the further document having associated user-interactive elements for selection of the message. Alternatively or additionally, the step of including a message comprises recording a customised message applied with the device to a message region of the document by capturing associated interaction data transmitted during movement of the device.

Preferably, the step of sending the card includes selecting the recipient address, using the device, from an address list provided with user-interactive elements. Alternatively, the step of sending the card includes writing the recipient address in an address field of a form using the sensing device and capturing the writing by recording the associated interaction data.

The recipient address may correspond to a printer address and the card is delivered by printing at that address. Alternatively, the recipient address corresponds to an electronic mail address and an image of the card is delivered to that address. As a further alternative the recipient address corresponds to a street address and the card is sent to a proximate mail service for printing and delivery to the street address.
Preferably, a preview of the card and message is provided in a further document for review prior to sending.

Preferably, the document includes coded data indicative of an identity of the document and of the at least one interactive element, and wherein the method includes receiving, in the computer system, indicating data from the sensing device regarding the identity of the document and a position of the sensing device relative to the document in order to identify the document and determine when the sensing device is used to interact with the element. The method may further include receiving, in the computer system, movement data regarding movement of the sensing device relative to the document with the sensing device preferably sensing its movement relative to the document using the coded data, and identifying the request in the computer system from the movement being at least partially within a zone associated with the interactive element. The coded data is preferably substantially invisible in the visible spectrum.
In yet another aspect, there is provided a system for enabling selection and delivery of a greeting card, including:
a printer for printing a document with coded data and details of available greeting cards;
a sensing device for reading the coded data and transmitting interaction data, representing interaction of the sensing device with the coded data, to allow for selection of a card; and
a computer system for receiving the interaction data from the device and transmitting the card to a recipient address.

Preferably, the computer system is adapted to include a message with the card, the message being user specified using the sensing device. More preferably, the computer system is adapted to receive movement data regarding movement of the sensing device relative to the coded data, in order to capture the message, and the sensing device preferably, senses its own movement relative to the document using the coded data.
Preferably, the sensing device includes a marking nib.
Preferably, the document is printed on a surface of a surface-defining structure and wherein the printer prints the document on demand.
Preferably, the printer is arranged to print the coded data at the same time as printing the document on a surface-defining structure.
Preferably, the coded data is substantially invisible in the visible spectrum.
The system preferably includes a database for keeping a retrievable record of each document generated, each document being retrievable by using its identity, as included in its coded data.
