titleStmt.title: METODO PARA CALCINAR POR LO MENOS PARCIALMENTE UN MATERIAL CRUDO CALCAREO PULVERULENTO PRECALENTADO
VERFAHREN UND VORRICHTUNG ZUM CALCINIEREN VON PULVERFOERMIGENM MATERIAL

item.name: F.L. SMIDTH & CO. A/S, KOEBENHAVN, DK
F.L. SMIDTH & CO. A/S, KOPENHAGEN/KOEBENHAVN, DK
F.L. SMIDTH & CO. OF CANADA, LIMITED

titleStmt.title: IMPROVEMENTS RELATING TO CALCINATION OF PULVEROUS MATERIA

div.p: 1434371 Preheating and burning cement raw materials F L SMIDTH & CO AS 29 Jan 1974 [14 March 1973] 12193/73 Heading F4B Apparatus for calcining lime bearing material, e.g. cement raw material comprises a shaft 1 connected by an offtake 2 to a separator, a bottom central duct 7 supplying oxidizing gas and enclosing a burner 8, and around the duct, an annular space 5 for a fluidized bed with supply pipes 12 for preheated material and a ring of inert fluidizing gas supply pipes 10. In a modification (Fig. 3) four burners 8 are used and in another modification (Figs. 4 and 5) the duct 7 is initially horizontal, terminating in a vortex producing manifold (7B) which gives a helical swirling motion to the oxidizing gas. The apparatus is shown, Fig. 6, incorporated in a suspension preheater of the multiple cyclone type associated with a rotary furnace 16 and a clinker cooler 21. The suspension preheater includes cyclones 24, 26 and 28, a material supply hopper 33 with a rotary feed valve 35, an exhaust fan 30, and a dust separator 31. Hot air from the cooler enters the duct 7 and waste gases from the furnace pass to one or all of line 43 feeding the fluidizing pipes 10, line 42 opening into riser pipe 25 or line 41 passing to cooling tower 44 and then to the intake of fan 30. Preheated raw material from hopper 26 passes to a valve casing 39 sharing it between the supply pipes 12 and calcined material from the shaft 1 passes from cyclone 24 to the rotary furnace 16. Alternatively, the one-stringed cyclone preheater may be double-stringed or even four stringed as in Specification 1,319,009.
WHAT WE CLAIM IS: -

1 A method of carrying out at least the partial calcination of a preheated pulverous raw material consisting of or containing lime, wherein an accumulation of the preheated pulverous raw material is fluidised by means of an incombustible gas which is caused to traverse the accumulation from below at such velocity that it partly causes the surface of the accumulation of raw material, intensely mixed with gas, to overflow a weir, and partly continuously entrains particles of raw material from the accumulation carrying them in suspension to an overlying space, and there is maintained in the space at least one flame by the burning of fuel with oxygencontaining gas which is supplied to the flame and which entrains the mixture of gas/raw material overflowing the weir, the arrangement being such that the necessary amount of heat for calcining at least partially the particles of raw material suspended in the incombustible gas and oxygen-containing gas is transmitted from the flame or flames to the suspension of raw material particles, the particles thus treated being subsequently carried away suspended in a conveying gas mixture composed of combustion gas from the flame or flames, of carbon dioxide expelled from the particles of raw material by the calcination and of the incombustible fluidisation gas, for separation from the conveying gas mixture.

2 A method according to claim 1, in which a part of the fuel, which by its combustion supplies heat for carrying out the calcination of the preheated raw material, instead of directly nourishing the flame or flames, is fed to and mixed with the fluid 70 ised accumulation of preheated pulverous raw material, and thus caused in a gaseous state together with the material to enter the space above the fluidised accumulation, where it is subsequently burnt 75 3 A method according to claim 1 or claim 2, in which a part of the preheated pulverous raw material, instead of being fed to the accumulation, is suspended in the oxygen-containing gas and passed together 80 with the oxygen-containing gas into the space where the fuel is burnt.

4 A method according to any one of the preceding claims, in which the raw materials after being at least partially cal 85 cined are subjected to a finishing calcination and/or any other heat treatment, and the incombustible gas which is used for fluidising the accumulation of raw material is constituted by a part of the waste gases 90 from the finishing calcination and/or other heat treatment.

A method according to any one of the preceding claims, in which the raw materials, after being at least partially cal 95 cined, are subjected to a finishing calcination and/or any other heat treatment and subsequently to a cooling process by means of atmospheric cooling air, at least part of the used cooling air from the cooling pro 100 cess being used again in the oxygen-containing gas which is supplied to the flame or flames.
6 A method according to any one of the preceding claims, in which the weir 105 surrounds an upward flow of the oxygencontaining gas.

7 A method according to claim 6, in which the upward flow of oxygen-containing gas exercises a helical swirling action 110 8 A method according to claim 1, substantially as described with reference to Figures 1 to 3, or to Figures 4 and 5, of the accompanying drawings.
9 Cement raw metal which has been at 115 least partially calcined by a method according to any one of the preceding claims.

A calcination plant for carrying out the method according to any one of claims 1 to 8, the plant comprising an upright shaft 120 which provides a calcination chamber and the upper end of which is connected to a particle/gas separator and forms an exit for calcined raw material suspended in gas, a supply duct for oxygen-containing gas 125 opening substantially centrally into the bottom of the calcination chamber, one or more burner pipes extending from below up through the supply duct and opening substantially level with the mouth of the 130 1,434,371 supply duct, means for feeding fuel through the burner pipe or pipes for producing a flame in the calcination chamber at the mouth of each burner pipe, a support formed adjacent to the bottom of the calcination chamber for supporting a fluidised accumulation of pulverous, preheated raw material to a level determined by a weir which separates the interior of the support from the flow of oxygen-containing gas from the supply pipe, means for feeding incombustible gas into the support from below to maintain the fluidised accumulation of material in the support and means for continuously feeding preheated, pulverous raw material to the support.

11 A plant according to claim 10, in which the calcination chamber is of circular cross-section and the fluidised bed support takes the form of an annular groove formed in the bottom of the chamber and surrounding the mouth of the feeding duct for oxygen-containing gas, the mouth constituting the weir.
12 A plant according to claim 11, in which the supply duct causes the oxygencontaining gas to exercise a helical swirling action as it passes up through the calcination chamber.
13 A plant according to claim 10, substantially as described with reference to Figures 1 to 3, or to Figures 4 and 5, of the accompanying drawings.
14 A cement burning plant incorporating a calcination plant according to any one of claims 10 to 13.
A cement burning plant according to claim 14, substantially as described with reference to Figure 6 of the accompanying drawings.
For the Applicants, GILL, JENNINGS & EVERY, Chartered Patent Agents, 51/52 Chancery Lane,London WC 2 A WHN.
Printed for Her Majesty's Stationery Office by Burgess & Son (Abingdon), Ltd -1976.
Published at The Patent Office, 25 Southampton Buildings, London, WC 2 A l AY from which copies may be obtained.
PATENT SPECIFICATION

( 21) Application No 12193173 ( 22) Filed 14 March 1973 ( 11) 1434 371 ( 19) ( 23) Complete Specification filed 29 Jan 1974 ( 44) Complete Specification published 5 May 1976 ( 51) INT CL 2 F 27 B 15/10 C 04 B 7/44 ( 52) Index at acceptance F 4 B 7 C 1 OB 7 Cl D 7 C 5 7 V 1 A 10 C 9 ( 72) Inventor JORN TOUBORG ( 54) IMPROVEMENTS RELATING TO CALCINATION OF PULVEROUS MATERIAL ( 71) We, F L SMIDTH & Co A/S, a Danish company, of 77 Vigerslev Alle, Copenhagen-Valby, Denmark, do hereby declare the invention, for which we pray that a patent may be granted to us, and the method by which it is to be performed, to be particularly described in and by the
following statement: -

This invention relates to at least the partial calcination of a preheated pulverous raw material, consisting of or containing lime, for example cement raw meal, by the supply of heat before the material is subjected to any finishing calcination and/or any other final heat treatment Calcination in this context is to be understood as expulsion of carbon dioxide from calcium carbonate (Ca OI Ca O+CO 2), which is an endothermic process When the raw material is cement raw meal the aforesaid heat treatment following the calcination is a sintering by which cement clinker is produced The sintering is an exothermic process.

The heat necessary for carrying through the conversion of cement raw meal to cement clinker is usually obtained by burning fuel introduced together with combustion air into a combustion chamber in which the fuel burns successively with the combustion air and forms exit gas As a result, the energy of the fuel is released for heating the exit gas to a high temperature.

The hot exit gas is then brought into contact with the raw meal to be heat treated, i.e preheated, calcined and burned The heat treatment usually takes place as a continuous process in a rotary kiln with slightly inclining axis If so, the lower lying end of the rotary kiln is as is usual for rotary kilns designed as a combustion chamber.

However, in the manufacture of cement the trend is to carry through preheating and calcination of the raw meal separately by means of hot gas from one source of heat and sintering of the raw meal in a rotary kiln by means of hot gas from another source of heat, that is the flame of the rotary kiln.

As far as the calcination is concerned relatively large quantities of materials have to be subjected to a relatively low heating, that is, the process takes place at a rather low temperature which is often inconsistent with the use of exit gases of a high temperature for carrying through the calcination.

There is a great risk of excessively heating the raw meal locally and temporarily and even a brief period of excessively heating a part of the raw meal may cause expulsion of alkali vapours or produce melts which may involve caking problems Furthermore, excessive heating of the raw meal at the calcination stage may prevent chemical reactions intended for a later stage of the whole process of manufacturing cement clinker For example, the formation of clinker minerals at such stage of the whole heat treatment process at which calcination is to take place involves an unfavourable development of the whole process.
It is the object of the invention to devise a process and a plant for carrying out the process which reduces the drawbacks previously referred to.

In the process according to the invention an accumulation of preheated pulverous raw material, which consists of or contains lime, is fluidised by means of an incombustible gas which is caused to traverse the accumulation from below at such velocity that it partly causes the surface of the accumulation of raw material, intensely mixed with gas, to overflow a weir, and partly continuously entrains particles of raw material from the accumulation carrying them in suspension to an overlying space and there is maintained in the space at least one flame by the burning of fuel with oxygen-containing gas, such as combustion air, which is supplied to the flame and which entrains the mixture of gas/raw material over-flowing the weir, the arrange1,434,371 ment being such that the necessary amount of heat for calcining at least partially the particles of raw material suspended in the incombustible gas and oxygen-containing gas is transmitted from the flame or flames to the suspension of raw material particles, the particles thus treated being subsequently carried away suspended in a conveying gas mixture composed of combustion gas from the flame or flames, of carbon dioxide expelled from the particles of raw material by the calcination and of the incombustible fluidisation gas, for separation from the conveying gas mixture.

The essential feature of the process is thus that the flame supplying the heat for carrying out the calcination is formed at the place where the raw materials are present, suspended in a gas, and where a fluidised accumulation of preheated raw material placed near the flame serves as source for the suspension of raw material particles in gas.

When carried out in this way, the process ensures that the flame immediately comes into contact with a cloud of relatively cool particles of raw material in whirling suspension in a gas, by which the flame temperature is lowered so much that an efficient calcination is obtained at a desired low temperature, and approximately isothermally In many cases the flame dwindles to almost nothing The cloud of gas whirling preferably about horizontal axes with suspended particles of raw material protect the walls bounding the flame space against excessive heat from the flame or flames.

The use of the term "partial calcination" in the present context is due to the fact that the whole process of cement burning is often carried through in such a manner that only a partial calcination takes place at the calcination stage, whereas the finishing calcination is effected at the sintering stage Cases may also be assumed in which the preheated raw meal fed to the calcination stage has already been subjected to a certain calcination in the preheater.

The fuel for the calcination may be a gas, an oil or a solid, pulverous fuel, for example coal powder, but anyway it is a gas that is burning, in the two last-mentioned cases, in the form of oil vapour and coal gas respectively.

A part of the fuel which by its combustion supplies heat for carrying out the calcination of the preheated material, may, instead of directly nourishing the flame or flames, be fed to and mixed with the fluidised accumulation of preheated pulverous raw material, and thus caused in a gaseous state together with the material to enter the space above the fluidised accumulation, 65 where it is subsequently burnt.

In this context it should be observed that in contrast it is known from our British Patent Application No 57071/72 (Serial No 1,428,680) to mix hie whole of the fuel 70 with the fluidised accumulation of preheated pulverous raw material.

In certain cases the process may advantageously be modified in that a part of the preheated pulverous material instead of 75 being fed to the accumulation is suspended in the oxygen-containing gas and passed together with the oxygen-containing gas into the space where the fuel is burnt.

In cases where the raw materials, having 80 been at least partially calcined, are subjected to a finishing calcination and/or other heat treatment, the incombustible gas which is used for fluidising the accumulation of raw material may be constituted by 85 a part of the waste gases from the finishing calcination and/or other heat treatment.

This supplementary heat treatment of the raw material is often succeeded by a cooling of the final product by causing a mov 90 ing layer thereof to be swept and/or traversed by cooling air in a cooler of known type, such as a grate cooler, a separate planetary cooler, or an underlying rotating drum cooler The oxygen-containing gas is 95 preferably preheated to a temperature below the calcination temperature of the raw material and at least part of the used cooling air from the aforementioned cooling process may thus be used again in the oxy 100 gen-containing gas which is supplied to the flame or flames The economy of the process is thus improved.
Preferably, the weir surrounds an upward flow of the oxygen containing gas, which 105 may then exer-cise a helical swirling action.

The invention also includes calcination apparatus for carrying out the new method, the plant comprising an upright shaft which provides a calcination chamber and the 110 upper end of which is connected to a particle/gas separator and forms an exit for calcined raw material suspended in gas, a supply duct for oxygen-containing gas opening substantially centrally into the bot 115 tom of the calcination chamber, one or more burner pipes extending from below up through the supply duct and opening substantially level with the mouth of the supply duct, means for feeding fuel through 120 the burner pipe or pipes for producing a flame in the calcination chamber at the mouth of each burner pipe, a support formed adjacent to the bottom of the calcination chamber for supporting a fluidised 125 accumulation of pulverous, preheated raw material to a level determined by a weir which separates the interior of the support from the flow of oxygen-containing gas 1,434,371 from the supply pipe, means for feeding incombustible gas into the support from below to maintain the fluidised accumulation of material in the support and means for continuously feeding preheated, pulverous raw material to the support.

Preferably, the calcination chamber is of circular cross-section and the fluidised bed support takes the form of an annular groove formed in the bottom of the chamber and surrounding the mouth of the feeding duct for oxygen-containing gas, the mouth constituting the weir In that case the supply duct may be arranged to cause the oxygen-containing gas to exercise a helical swirling action as it passes up through the calcination chamber.

Examples of a cement burning plant incorporating a calcination plant and another example of calcination plant according to the invention are illustrated in the accompanying drawings, in which: Figure 1 shows, in vertical section, one plant for the calcination of cement raw meal; Figure 2 is a horizontal section taken on the line II-II in Figure 1; Figure 3 is a horizontal section taken on the line III-III in Figure 1 but showing a modified plant; Figure 4 is a view similar to Figure 1 but of the other calcination plant; Figure 5 is a section taken on the line V-V in Figure 4; and, Figure 6 is a diagrammatic representation of the complete cement burning plant, incorporating the calcination plant of Figure 1 as an integral part.
The apparatus shown in Figures 1 and 2 has a shaft forming a calcination chamber 1 and provided with a fire-resistant lining.

The shaft is cylindrical and of circular cross-section although other shapes are possible It is restricted at its upper part so as to form a discharge pipe 2 for wholly or partly calcined particles of raw material.
The pipe leads to a particle/gas separator such as a cyclone (not shown in Figures 1 and 2), into which it opens tangentially.

The chamber 1 has an annular bottom wall 3 and with a central upstanding frustoconical wall 4 so as to form a support receptacle 5 which is open above and takes the form of an annular groove, defined by the bottom wall 3, by the wall of the shaft and by the wall 4 The upper edge of the wall 4 forms a weir 6 which at the same time constitutes the mouth of a vertical supply pipe 7 for combustion air introduced into the shaft 1 from below.

A burner pipe 8 for the supply of gaseous, liquid or solid pulverous fuel (for example coal powder) is introduced into the supply pipe 7 and passed centrally up to open almost on level with the weir 6, where the fuel forms a flame, nourished by the oxygen of combustion air fed through the supply pipe 7 when the plant is operating.

Supply pipes 10 for incombustible gas, for example atmospheric air under pres 70 sure and supplied through a pipe 11, open at the bottom of the receptacle 5 Beneath the shaft the pipe 11 is formed as an annular pipe connected to all the supply pipes 10, which are uniformly distributed 75 around a circle, as shown in Figure 2, or along two or more concrete circles The incombustible gas supplied in finely divided streams fluidises the accumulation of preheated raw meal which is maintained in the 80 receptacle 5 by a continual supply of fresh raw meal through one or more supply pipes 12 In Figures 1 and 2 two such supply pipes are illustrated and the raw meal for each of the two pipes 12 is fed continually 85 each from its separate cyclone of which only part of the bottom 13 is indicated.
Each of the two cyclones constitutes the lowermost cyclone in its separate string of a two-stringed conventional cyclone pre 90 heater (not shown) for preheating cement raw meal.

Though the preheated raw meal forms a fairly well defined surface 14, its aeration is nevertheless so powerful that raw meal 95 almost in a form-like state partly overflows the weir 6, from the receptacle 5, and partly is carried by the fluidisation gas into the space denoted 15 within the chamber 1 above the surface 14 as the air forces its 100 way up through the surface 14 In similar manner the raw meal having overflown the weir 6 is entrained by the combustion air coming from the supply pipe 7 Both the raw meal entrained by the fluidisation gas 105 and that entrained by the combustion air will thus for a time be present in the space 15, suspended in gas However, in the gas eddies will be formed, mainly about horizontal axes, owing to the combustion air 110 ascending from the central supply pipe 7.

As a result nearly all the raw meal in the form of free-laid particles receives sooner or later sufficient heat from the flame 9 to enable a substantial part of the raw meal 115 to be wholly calcined, and the balance of raw meal to be almost wholly calcined, at a low temperature and essentially isothermally.

The raw meal thus treated is removed 120 from the top of the chamber 1 through the pipe 2, suspended in a gas mixture composed of combustion gas from the flame 9, carbon dioxide developed by calcination of the raw material particles, and fluidisation 125 gas supplied from the pipes 10.

Figure 3 gives an outline of a detail of the calcination apparatus based upon the formation not only of one flame 9 but upon four such flames In that case there is not 130 1,434,371 one central burner pipe 8 but four such ( pipes denoted 8 ', distributed symmetrically i in the supply pipe 7 and receiving the fuel l which is then preferably gas or oil from t an annular pipe 8 " fed from a common I feeding pipe 8 "' The modification illustrated in Figures 4 and 5 differs from the Figure 1 example in that the combustion air supply pipe 7 is fed laterally through a branch 7 A which leads i into a vortex producing manifold 7 B which in turn causes the air to exercise a helical swirling action as it passes up through the space 15 as indicated by the arrowed line.

In this case eddy currents like those indicated by the curves or arrows in the Figure 1 example will not be formed, but the helical swirling motion of the gas will have the same effect as the eddies, although their common axis of rotation is vertical in this case instead of horizontal.

Figure 6 shows diagrammatically a plant for the manufacture of cement clinker on the basis of cold cement raw meal In the installation the calcination plant shown in Figures 1 and 2 constitutes an integral part, although, by simple adaption the Figures 4 and 5 plant could equally well be incorporated Parts shown in Figure 4 that are common with those of Figures 1 and 2 are therefore provided with the same reference numerals.
Thus, in Figure 6 there is also the chamber 1 with the discharge pipe 2 and the supply pipes 7, 10, 11 and 12.

In addition there is a rotary kiln 16 in which the preheated and wholly or partially calcined raw meal after finished calcination, if any, is burnt to cement clinker The heat for carrying through these kiln processes is obtained from gaseous, liquid or solid pulverous fuel fed to the interior of the kiln through a burner pipe 17 at the mouth of which there is formed a flame 18.

The hot gases from the burner pipe are passed through the slightly inclining kiln counter-currently to the calcined raw meal sliding down through the kiln in turbulence, swept by the kiln gases, by which burning of the raw meal to form cement clinker takes place.
The exit gases leave the kiln through a chamber 19 surrounding the upper kiln end; and the exit gases proceed through a gas pipe which is indicated in the Figure simply by a stippled line 20.

Similarly the lower kiln end is surrounded by a casing 21, which also surrounds a cooler, in which the clinker leaving the kiln at a temperature of 1110012000 is cooled to about 1000 C by the passage of atmospheric air, which is consequently heated and then utilised as preheated combustion air both in the rotary kiln 16 and in the chamber 1 The cooler consists of a grate 22, on which the clinker s distributed in a layer of suitable thickless The layer of clinker then moves coninuously away from the kiln, penetrated by transverse streams of cooling air supplied 70 under pressure through a cooling air supply pipe 23 to the space below the grate 22 The extreme end of the cooler from which the cooled clinker is discharged is not shown in the Figure Having passed through the 75 layer of clinker, the cooling air now preheated flows along the paths indicated by arrows, partly into the rotary kiln 16, partly through the supply pipe 7, which is connected to the upper end of the casing 80 21, and into the chamber 1 as described in connection with Figure 1.

With reference to Figure 1 it was further mentioned that the discharge pipe 2 for calcined raw meal suspended in the waste 85 gas from the calcination process was to be introduced tangentially into a cyclone This is shown in Figure 4 and denoted 24 In this cyclone the calcined raw meal is separated from the waste gases and settles on the 90 bottom of the cyclone, whilst the waste gases leave the cyclone through an upper central riser pipe 25.

The riser pipe 25 with a corresponding cyclone 26 and another riser pipe 27 with 95 a corresponding cyclone 28 constitute a conventional two-stage cyclone preheater in which the cold raw meal is preheated by means of the waste gases from the calcination process before it is calcined itself 100 From the top of the uppermost cyclone 28 of the cyclone preheater the waste gases are introduced through a central discharge pipe 29 into a fan 30 which produces the necessary sub-atmospheric pressure to cause 105 the gas flow to take the path determined by the reference numerals 23, 21, 22, 7, 1, 2, 24, 25, 26, 27, 28, 29 and 30 The delivery side of fan 30 opens into a dust precipitator 31 in which dust contained in the waste 110 gases is removed so that they may escape through a vent pipe 32 into the atmosphere without causing damage.

The cold raw meal to be preheated, calcined and burnt to cement clinker is fed 115 from a hopper 33 and sinks from the hopper into a feed pipe 34 which is fitted with a rotary gate valve 35 which prevents simultaneous intake of atmospheric air into the feed pipe 34 The other end of the pipe 120 34 opens into the lower end of the riser pipe 27 for the uppermost cyclone 28 of the cyclone preheater, which means that there is a sub-atmospheric pressure in the whole cyclone preheater, and also in the pipe 27, 125 since the cyclone preheater is connected with the suction side of the fan 30.

The raw meal fed is suspended in and heated by the hot gases ascending through the riser pipe 27 and is subsequently intro 130 1,434,371 duced into the cyclone 28, in which the preheated raw meal is separated off and sinks to the bottom of the cyclone, leaving the cyclone through a feed pipe 36 into which is inserted a rotary gate valve 37 serving the same purpose as the rotary gate valve 35 The raw meal is then introduced through the lower end of the riser pipe 25 into the lowermost preheater cyclone 26, suspended in the gases ascending through the riser pipe 25 In the cyclone 26 the further preheated raw meal and the gases are again separated, the gases following the path already described, whereas the raw meal sinks to the bottom of the cyclone 26 and hence into a feed pipe 38.

If the arrangement according to Figure 6 had conformed fully to the plant shown in Figures 1 and 2 which foresees the use not of a single-string, but of a two-string cyclone preheater, there would have been two cyclones 26, one for each string and each having a separate feed pipe 38 The bottoms of the two cyclones and their feed pipes would then have conformed to the parts 13 and 12, respectively, of Figure 1.

Now according to Figure 4 the use of a cyclone preheater with one string only is foreseen In order nevertheless to have two feed pipes 12 passed to the receptacle 5 inside the shaft 1 so as to obtain a uniform distribution of preheated raw meal in the receptacle 5, the feed pipe 38 of the plant shown in Figure 6 has been branched into two pipes, both denoted 12, since they correspond to the pipes referred to as branch pipes in Figure 1 A uniform distribution of preheated raw meal to the two branch pipes 12 is effected by means of an adjustable damper located in a casing 39.

The raw meal calcined in the shaft 1 and separated from the gas in the cyclone 24 and the further passage of which has already been described is passed through a pipe 40 into the rotary kiln 16, in which the raw meal is converted to clinker as already described.

The heated solid particles of material contained in the exit gases of the rotary kiln leaving the kiln along the path indicated by the stippled line 20 may be utilised in various manner depending on the path indicated by the stippled lines 41, 42, and 43 along which the kiln gas may be passed.
Depending on the circumstances only one of the paths, two of them, or all three of them may be used.

If the kiln gases, or part thereof, flow as indicated by the stippled line 41, they unite with waste gases from the calcination of the raw meal in the shaft 1 directly before they are sucked into the fan 30 by which they are forced into the dust precipitator 31.

Since the precipitator cannot withstand an excessive gas temperature, there is inserted a cooling tower 44 in the circuit as illustrated diagrammatically In the cooling tower the gases are cooled by water As a result the heat contained in the gases is lost unless the heat transmitted to the cooling water 70 can be utilised The solid particles, that is, dust contained in the waste gases, are, however, intercepted together with dust contained in the waste gases from calcination and preheating in the dust precipitator 31 75 and may, unless the dust contains an excessive amount of alkalis or chlorine, be fed to the rotary kiln 16, for example by being introduced into the pipe 40 as indicated by a stippled line 45 80 If the exit gases from the rotary kiln 16 or a part thereof follow the stippled line 42, they unite with the waste gases from the calcination of the raw meal effected in the chamber 1 and are introduced together 85 with the latter gases into the cyclone preheater ( 25, 26, 27, 28, 29) In that case the heat contained in the rotary kiln gases is utilised as a contribution to preheat the raw meal and consequently to improve the 90 economy of the process The gases are cooled correspondingly and may therefore without damage pass with the waste gases from the calcination through the fan 30 into the dust precipitator 31, in which the total 95 amount of dust is intercepted to be utilised if required as described in the foregoing.

If the exit gases from the rotary kiln 16, or a part thereof, follow the stippled line 43, they are introduced in the pipe 11 in 100 stead of atmospheric air, and they will thus via the feed pipes 10 constitute the air that effects the fluidisation of the preheated raw meal in the receptacle 5 (see Figure 1).

As a result of the heat contained in the gas, 105 the raw meal will be further heated while it is traversed by the gas from below Solid particles contained in the gas mix with the other particles which are being suspended in the gas present in the shaft 1 in the space 110 above the receptacle 5 (see Figure 1).

Reference has been made in the foregoing to alternative conveying paths in connection with Figure 6, indicated by stippled lines 115 Also in Figure 1 certain alternatives are illustrated Thus, the stippled lines 46 indicate that a part of the preheated raw meal from the cyclones 13 instead of being passed with the remaining material to the 120 receptacle 5 is introduced into the feed pipe 7 for combustion air, so as to be suspended therein and passed into the space 15.

Further stippled lines 47 suggest that a part of the fuel, instead of being fed 125 directly to the flame 9 through burner pipe 8, may be branched off from the pipe and introduced into the bottom end of the receptacle 5 similarly as the fluidisation air is fed through the pipes 11 and 10 Unless 130 1,434,371 the fuel is already in a gaseous state, it will be converted to gas or vapours (forming oil vapours or coal gas) when meeting the hot raw meal The gas will ascend together with the fluidisation air through the accumulation of raw meal.

The plant shown in Figure 6 should only be considered an example showing how it may be designed and many modifications may come in for consideration Thus, it has already been suggested that the cyclone preheaters 25, 26, 27, 28, 29 may be onestringed or two-stringed, but it may, for example, also be four-stringed as the preheater protected by our British Patent Application No 56051/71 (Serial No.

1428680) If so, it will be natural to pass four feed pipes 12, staggered 900 in relation to one another, to the receptacle Instead of two-stage preheaters on Q-stage preheaters or four-stage preheaters may be used.

Furthermore a suspension preheater of a type different from that of the cyclone preheater may be used for preheating the raw meal, and also a clinker cooler other than the grate cooler 21, 22 and 23 may be used after the rotary kiln 16, for example an underlying independently rotating cooling drum or an independently rotating planetary cooler.
